entry.title: Thoughts on owning a website
entry.summary:
Earlier today, I was writing up a web design client info sheet. I was kind of proud of a couple parts of it, so I thought I'd paste them in here:

Having a website should be a responsibility.

  • You should check the entire site from time to time to make sure that information is current and accurate.
  • If you have dates on your site, they should be kept current. For example, a blog or news section should be updated frequently and regularly. If the most recent news item is from sometime in 2006, the site will not be credible to viewers.
  • In the same way, people change over time. If you have photos of staff or other people on your site, the photos should be kept current.
  • Don’t spread yourself too thin - don’t take on more than you can handle in a website. If you have two blogs, a news section, recent photos, and a section of restaurant reviews, you probably will be burned out trying to keep it all up-to-date.

Use your site as a part of your marketing strategy.

  • Maintain other marketing materials as well, not everyone is online
  • Reference your site in your other marketing materials
  • Make sure that your site exists for your customers, not for you. Consider why people are coming to your site and what information they will be looking for - and make this information easy to get. For example, on a software download site, users probably won’t want to read a long statement about the history and development of the software - instead, the “Download” button should be prominently displayed and the download process should be simple.

Do you like your site well enough that it can replace Google as your home page? I actually enjoy browsing through my own site. I figure, if I like it so much, my target audience should also. Of course, this is a general statement, but it’s a good rule of thumb.

entry.title: Google Maps route elevation profiles
entry.summary:
Welcome! Note that this article is several years old. Please excuse me for pointing out things that are more obvious now... like how to plot a route on Google Maps :) The GPSVisualizer tip partway through the article is still good and I use it regularly.

This isn't anything I've made, but it's a cool combination of tools I came across for mapping running and biking routes and finding their elevation profiles.

Google Maps introduced a very cool "routes" feature a while back that allows you to find directions between two points, and drag that route around to find alternate routes. You can add intermediate destinations or "node" points along the route. I've been finding distances of potential biking routes by simply using Google Maps.

Once at the Google Maps website, right-click at the starting point of your route and choose "Directions from Here". Follow your route to major intersection, and right-click on the map again and choose "Directions To Here". Google Maps will automatically fill in a suggested route. If you don't like it, click and drag it until it's the route you'd like to take between those two points.

After this, find another point along your route and choose "Add Destination". Again, adjust the route if you want. Google will usually choose the most direct driving route from point to point. Keep adding more destinations until you're at the finish!

Usually you can map a lengthy run with 5-10 destinations. This is MUCH quicker than using route mapping tools like the USATF running route tool, where it draws a straight line between each point you click on the map. The drawback is that routes are more limited to roads, so this would be pointless on a trail route.

So now you have a nice running or cycling route, with accurate distance. Now, directly above the map, you'll see the words "Print, Send, Link" in the blue bar. Click "Link" and copy the email/IM link given. Head over to http://www.gpsvisualizer.com and click "Draw a profile" in the top menu.

Find the box that says "Or provide the URL of Data on the Web" at bottom right of the page. Paste your map link here. This site will generate an elevation profile graph of the route.

It only takes a few minutes to do this. I might consider working something like this into a future version of TrueGoal.

entry.title: R2CB!
entry.summary:
Roseburg to Coos Bay Relay was last weekend. I ran on a team with my family (all except David). Here's how things went:

  1. Drive to Coos Bay on Friday afternoon and watch the Coos County track meet. Eat some dinner.
  2. Wake up at 4:00 a.m. This run had better be a LOT of fun.
  3. Leave at 4:30 a.m. to drive to Roseburg in time for our 7:00 start.
  4. Start! My mom takes leg 1 out toward Lookingglass in the cool overcast weather. At least it's dry. Leg 1 is mostly uphill.
  5. We see a jeep drive by like three times during leg 2 (Dad) and leg 3 (Steph). On my leg (4), I see it being towed.
  6. I run leg 4. Still cloudy and cold. Leg 4 is flat at first, then starts going up... it goes up for a while, then downhill, then up again on a steeper hill. Overall not an easy leg, but I felt pretty good and did fine powering up the hill.
  7. Corey has leg 5. Ha ha ha ha ha! This is a nasty hill.
  8. Mom takes over on leg 6. This finishes off the hill from leg 5 and then goes downhill on the other side. The Coquille River starts up here, as a little trickle becoming a stream. The road changes to gravel and the clouds cleared off on this leg. For the rest of the run, it was sunny and really warm, although it cooled off a bit as we approached the coast of course.
  9. As Dad is running leg 7, we're driving down the gravel road in the middle of the forest, with waterfalls along the ever-growing Coquille River.
  10. We pick up some pavement on Steph's downhill leg 8.
  11. My leg 9 is flat, short, and hot. I didn't feel very good on this one. Not looking forward to the next one.
  12. After Corey's leg, Mom has a fun leg: 2 miles up, 2 miles down. Another runner was looking at the gentle slope rising from the exchange point, she said, "is it like this the whole way up?" Not really... she reaches the top of the hill spewing expletives... Mom says, "well, the last half mile was pretty steep, I guess".
  13. Fairview! Everyone's stopping at the store since it's the first one we've seen for hours. But Coos Bay is just over the hill..
  14. Up Blue Ridge, and down the other side on the gravel road to Sumner. Almost time for me to run my third leg...
  15. I get to run my last leg on the rolling hills from Sumner to the big hill I used to run several times a week to get to my house... I felt great, charged over the top of the big hill and down Ross Inlet Road.
  16. Corey finishes off by running into Eastside then Coos Bay and finishing at Freddy's.
  17. Time to get some 'za at Abby's. We were third in our division in 9:27:26.

entry.title: New Salem bridge!
entry.summary:
The old railroad bridge over the Willamette River has been converted to a pedestrian/bike bridge and is open now! It connects Riverfront Park and Wallace Marine Park. Riverfront Park is a grassy park with a carousel and wide concrete walking paths, and lots of community festivals and things are held there; Wallace Marine is a little more wild and has a reputation as the location of several homeless camps. Hopefully the increased foot and bike traffic in the area - along with city and volunteer efforts to clean out some undergrowth and maintain running trails in the park - will make the park a more pleasant place to be.

As you can see, the bridge isn't much of a looker, but it's nice to have.

Even though it doesn't look beautiful from a distance, it's not unpleasant when you're there.

There's a lead paint issue on the bridge, it's flaking off on places like this. It's been sealed 6-8 feet above the walkway, the picture here shows an area above that. As far as I know, the bridge will be closed over next winter so the issue can be taken care of.

Hey, Salem's got something cool now! In your FACE, Bend!

entry.title: Fruit on the Bottom - a yogurt review
entry.summary:
As I sit here eating a cup of yogurt, it occurs to me: Who invented fruit-on-the-bottom yogurt? Is it good? Of course, I have an opinion about this.

Now, I'm not generally an "instant-gratification, I-want-everything-right-now" kind of guy. But I can't help but think that the fruit is put on the bottom simply to add an extra layer of preparation before I can enjoy my yogurt. I not only have to remove the lid and weird little foil thing, I have to stir the fruit into the yogurt. Sometimes, I rush the stirring a little too much, and end up spilling a glob of yogurt on the table, floor, or myself (yeah, I can hear you snickering already. This is purely an indictment of the yogurt companies, or as I call them, "Big Yogurt"; this has nothing to do with my strengths and weaknesses as a yogurt stirrer). Let's face it: Fruit-on-the-bottom is a poor user interface design for yogurt cups.

And what's the point anyway? If I stir the fruit into the yogurt, I've just spent an extra 30 seconds to bring my yogurt up to "blended yogurt" standards. The stirring (in my opinion) ruins the consistency and temperature of the yogurt and it's impossible to stir it up evenly anyways. There's always too much fruit left in the bottom. If I wanted my yogurt and fruit separate, I'd eat a bunch of plain yogurt then a couple spoonfuls of jam or a pineapple or something.

I am only one voice, but if enough of us speak up, Big Yogurt will eventually have to listen.

entry.title: We're back!
entry.summary:
We're back from our trip to Bend. It was a great trip. The weather was amazing (80's and sunny the whole time) and Bend seems like a pretty cool town. We have a few pictures up, just click "pictures" above.

Here's a quick run-down of the trip (links are to Google maps of trails):

Thursday: After arriving in Bend, we ran the First Street Rapids trail. This starts just a few blocks from downtown and is a dirt/gravel trail along the Deschutes river with views of mountains. Bend has lots of these kinds of trails within a few minutes of town. Thursday's dinner was at the McMenamin's downtown.

Friday's coffee was Bend Mountain Coffee. The run was atShevlin Park, a city park along the west end of town. It's got trails through the forest and feels further out than it really is. Dinner was Pizza Mondo.

Saturday's coffee was Maui Wowi (yes, that's what it is really called). Good coffee! Evelyn ran a trail from Larkspur Park to Pilot Butte, then up the butte, then cooled down back to the park. Again, it's cool that Bend has these trails in town. Dinner was... let's see... dinner was Bella Cucina, a little Italian restaurant in the Old Mill District.

Sunday's coffee was the Strictly Organic Coffee House. We ran at Shevlin Park again and stopped for smoothies from Maui Wowi on our way back into town. Dinner was Toomie's, a Thai restaurant downtown.

Monday's coffee was Backporch Coffee. They roast their own coffee and have some interesting blends. We ran on the Deschutes River Trail south of town. This was only a 10-minute drive from town! Shevlin Park was even closer. Did I mention that we were impressed with how much trail running there is in Bend? Dinner was at a seafood chain restaurant called Anthony's. It was nice!

Tuesday's coffee was Bellatazza. We then packed our stuff and left town. On the way back, we stopped in Sisters and ran the Eagle Rock Loop. And now we're home! And it's cloudy again!
